executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2021 currency. The Armored Vehicle Manufacturing industry experienced significant growth over the five years to 2021. Industry operators research, develop, manufacture, modify and repair military armored vehicles, including infantry fighting vehicles, armored personnel carriers, mine-resistant ambush protected (MRAP) vehicles, self-propelled artillery and armored utility vehicles. Prior to the five-year period, industry revenue declined dramatically as US spending on industry products fell. However, this trend reversed during the current five-year period as the United States began to increase defense spending and ramp up key industry programs. Consequently, industry revenue is expected to increase at an annualized rate of 10.2% to $4.6 billion over the five years to 2021, despite a decline of 12.4% in 2021.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Armored Vehicle Manufacturing industry has experienced strong growth over the five years to 2021
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Industry players research, develop, manufacture, modify and repair military armored vehicles. Prior to the current five-year period, industry revenue plunged as US military spending on industry products plummeted. However, during the current period, a pick-up in US defense spending and a ramp-up of key industry programs helped industry revenue to recover from earlier declines. Over the five years to 2021, industry revenue is estimated to rise an annualized 10.2% to $4.6 billion, despite a decline of 12.4% in 2021 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The primary driver of industry performance is demand from the US military
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The industry's increase in revenue is largely due to a pick-up in overall defense spending. The Department of Defense (DoD) not only purchases a majority of industry products but also establishes and funds the development of many new vehicles. Specifically, the DoD has invested billions into modernizing and upgrading its Bradley and Stryker armored vehicles. Moreover, the production of the new AMPV and the JLTV has created new industry revenue streams for years to come.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Over the five years to 2026, industry revenue is forecast to increase marginally
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Industry revenue is forecast to grow at an annualized rate of 0.1% to $4.6 billion in 2026. A rising budget deficit, boosted by accelerated government spending amid the COVID-19 pandemic, is expected to put downward pressure on industry growth. With wages growing faster than revenue, profit is expected to decline during the outlook period. Meanwhile, exports are expected to grow an annualized 0.4% to $857.3 million, driven by rising geopolitical tensions.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: The federal funding for defense is expected to grow
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2026, the federal funding for defense is expected to grow at an annualized rate of 0.3%. The military is currently investing in three major programs that will contribute to growth in industry revenue during the five-year period - the Amphibious Combat Vehicle (ACV), the Joint Light Tactical Vehicles (JLTV), and the Armored Multi-Purpose Vehicle (AMPV).

industry_definition: This industry includes establishments engaged in manufacturing, modifying, repairing and servicing military armored vehicles. These vehicles are used in combat to transport infantry and munitions or to provide combat support. Tanks are not included in this industry.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The US government accounts for an estimated 81.7% of industry revenue. The United States has the largest defense budget in the world and has an extensive armored vehicle fleet. As a result, industry operators have a large domestic market to operate in, with most contractors relying on the Department of Defense for the majority of their orders.

Exports are expected to account for 18.3% of industry revenue in 2021. The United States is one of the leading arms exporters in the world and sells industry products to a wide variety of allies and foreign governments.

products_and_services.product_description: Wheeled armored vehicles represent an estimated 60.0% of industry revenue in 2021. Known for their speed and relative lightness compared with tracked vehicles, wheeled armored vehicles can provide very quick armored transport of soldiers over large distances at a far lower cost than tracked vehicles.

Tracked armored vehicles are expected to represent an estimated 17.6% of industry revenue in 2021. As their name implies, tracked armored vehicles are combat vehicles that are propelled using a continuous track of steel plates. Tracked vehicles, such as the Bradley Fighting Vehicle and the M113, are designed to traverse rugged terrain and soft ground with less likelihood of becoming stuck or stalling.
The other segment is expected to account for 22.5% of industry revenue in 2021. This segment includes the manufacture of specialized parts and components, maintenance, support and repair services.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The leading demand determinant for the industry is US defense spending. The industry receives most of its revenue from Department of Defense (DoD) contracts. In turn, the US defense budget is determined by several factors, including geopolitical tensions, engagement in conflict, types of national threats and the fiscal condition of the government.

Exports typically account for a large portion of industry revenue and as a result, foreign demand for US armored vehicles plays an import role in the industry. As with the US, foreign defense budgets are the prime factor when it comes to demand. Increasing defense spending abroad increases demand for industry products.

As with all military products, technological change plays a vital role in demand for armored vehicles. Governments are constantly looking to gain an advantage over possible adversaries by developing superior weapon systems. Moreover, if rivals develop weapons that can more easily defeat or are superior to current US armored vehicles, the US government would be more willing to fund the development and procurement of next-generation industry products.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Industry exports account for an estimated 18.3% of industry revenue in 2021, a substantial decline from 2016. Much of this decline is due to a shrinking international market. Moving forward, industry exports will likely stagnate as the US has withdrawn from Afghanistan, despite an increase in non-NATO defense spending.

Over the five years to 2021, Taiwan's share of industry exports has grown exponentially, increasing from 0.3% of industry exports in 2016 to an estimated 13.1% of exports in 2021. Growth has been driven largely by increasing tensions between China and Taiwan in the second half of the period.

Industry imports is expected to account for 8.3% of domestic demand in 2021. Typically, the United States limits the import military equipment to maintain a technological lead and domestic production capacity. However, close US allies can supply the domestic market, explaining why they account for most imports.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region hosts the highest percentage of industry establishments, estimated to be 42.5% in 2021. The Great Lakes is home to General Dynamic Land Systems, the subsidiary of General Dynamics that manufacturers armored vehicles for both US armed forces and international allies. Oshkosh Corporation, the largest industry operator, is also located in the Great Lakes region.

The Southeast region has the second highest percentage of establishments at around 15%, followed by the West at around 12.5%. The remaining regions have lower percentages of establishments. On the other hand, the population distribution is more evenly spread across regions compared to the establishments. The Southeast has the highest population percentage at around 22%.
The West region has around 12.5% of industry establishments. The population percentage in the West is around 18%.
The Southwest region has a population percentage of around 15%.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The US government treats military vehicles as sensitive goods requiring export licensing and documentation prior to sale to foreign allies, regulated by multiple federal departments.
Manufacturers are subject to regulations concerning government contracts, including provisions for termination, audits, and payment terms based on acceptance of work.
Industry must comply with environmental laws and regulations concerning discharge of effluent, air quality standards, and water pollution from manufacturing plants.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Dependence on Department of Defense contracts
barriers_points.barrier_description: The success of armored vehicle manufacturers depends almost entirely on Department of Defense contracts to thrive. Virtually all participants fight for a share of the federal government's allocated defense budget.

barriers_points.barrier_title: Need for expertise, labor, capacity and reputation
barriers_points.barrier_description: Establishments need to possess the expertise, labor power, productive capacity and reputation to undertake major contracting projects. Proven experience and the ability to provide constant product improvement are vital due to the high expectations of the US military.

The initial setup cost associated with this industry is tremendous. Companies incur high capital investment costs to first gain access to large amounts of land and property, manufacturing plants, and testing facilities.
Many organizations incur high R&D costs. The industry's competitive nature requires significant investment in R&D and leveraging the expertise of highly skilled employees.

basis_points.basis_description: The industry has high initial investment costs since it requires extensive familiarity with military programs and a working relationship with the Department of Defense before it can become a contractor to the military.

While competition from new entrants is low, internal competition can often be intense. Armored vehicle production is one of the most competitive segments within the entire defense sector since many companies offer highly sophisticated technologies and constantly evolving vehicle specifications.

basis_points.basis_title: External competition from international markets and substitutes
basis_points.basis_description: The industry also experiences external competition from international markets and, to a lesser extent, substitutes.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The top four players estimated to hold a combined market share of 93.0% in 2021.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Major players receive most government contracts
concentration_points.concentration_description: General Dynamics Corporation, Oshkosh Corporation and BAE Systems are the primary recipients of government contracts for armored vehicle production.
When a major player receives a contract, some components are typically contracted out to subcontractors that also form part of the industry.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The largest cost for all industry establishments is purchases, which mainly consist of materials such as steel, ceramic, plastic, resins and welding materials. Another major component of purchases comes from electronic systems.

The proportion of revenue allocated to depreciation illustrates the high level of capital costs within the industry. Depreciation costs account for manufacturing equipment, communication equipment, office equipment, technology and software.
Research and development (R&D) accounts for a large portion of industry revenue, as operators have to invest into new technology to stay ahead of the competition and attract government contracts.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Manufacturing of armored vehicles requires considerable investment into heavy equipment and large facilities. Computer-controlled machine tools are standard fixtures in machining operations.
Industry operators also employ workers who operate machinery, perform assembly and service vehicles. Moreover, many workers are unionized and have certification, thereby increasing average wages.
The level of capital intensity has declined as industry operators have continued to allocate more resources to research and development.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Before the current period, the US military procured a large number of armored vehicles for combat operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. However, once production plunged, so did revenue.
More recently, volatility climbed as steep declines were offset by a pickup in growth driven by increased procurement of certain products.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: The industry's manufactured products involve highly sophisticated technologies and systems. Armored vehicles have become integrated with a range of features, electronics, communications and enhancements.

Companies have introduced industrial robot systems for welding, painting, assembly and testing. Computer-aided design, manufacturing and numerically controlled machine tools have improved accuracy and reduced costs.
Major manufacturers employ computer-aided automation which has significantly improved the production process. Operators are focusing on improving vehicle capability through combat and safety systems.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or produce a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Specializing in a single product, such as MRAPs, has left many such producers exposed to falling demand for these vehicles.

FAQs.question: Have export markets like Canada and Mexico offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: Exports has fallen sharply during the past five years, driven by a decline in export to Afghanistan and Saudi Arabia in the second half of the current period. Taiwan's share of industry exports has grown considerably during the past five years, driven by rising tensions with China.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: The price of steel can be volatile and can threaten profit margins if it rises quickly. World price of steel has exhibited high volatility during the past five years.

FAQs.question: Do you have any big projects requiring that require capital financing on the horizon?
FAQs.answer: A number of new US government contracts have forced industry players to retool factories.

FAQs.question: Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: Since the US government is the industry's biggest customer, operators rarely have difficulty with late payments. However, recent budget uncertainty has made funding less predictable.

FAQs.question: Does your company provide after-sales advice to customers? Does your company generate revenue through accessory sales?
FAQs.answer: The operator's ability to provide service and enhancements on equipment after the initial sale will greatly improve relationships with clients.

FAQs.question: How much time is invested in research and development? What are the associated costs?
FAQs.answer: Research and development for armored vehicles is constantly evolving, and successful operators must continually improve upon vehicle features, specifications, safety requirements and other regulations mandated by the US armed forces.

FAQs.question: How do you hire workers? What is your training process like?
FAQs.answer: Due to the technical complexity involved in manufacturing armored vehicles, highly skilled and specialized labor is necessary to remain competitive.

FAQs.question: How closely do you track the trade-weighted index? How much of your business comes from international clients?
FAQs.answer: A decreasing TWI leads to relatively less expensive exports and more expensive imports. Therefore, industry operators benefit from a weak US dollar through increased demand for exports as well as weaker import competition for the same goods.

FAQs.question: Do you have a reliable supplier of steel? How do you offset the effects of rising steel prices?
FAQs.answer: Steel is one of the primary inputs in the production of armored vehicles. An increase in price for steel typically leads to higher revenue as there are few substitutes for armored vehicles, and demand doesn't change significantly even when the price of steel rises.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your business comes from government contracts? How has reduced federal defense spending influenced your revenue in recent years?
FAQs.answer: The industry is highly sensitive to defense spending. More specifically, the amount set aside solely for the procurement and maintenance of armored vehicles is the most important driver of industry revenue. In 2021, US government contracts are expected to represent 81.7% of industry revenue.
